title: 114_s1153
content: The "Red River Private Property Protection Act" disclaims any right to land south of the Red River's South Bank boundary line. Previous surveys by the Bureau of Land Management will not determine the current boundary line. The Secretary will commission a new survey to identify the South Bank boundary line along the affected area, adhering to specific criteria and completed within 2 years. The survey will be approved by the Texas General Land Office to satisfy the requirements of the Act. SEC. 4. APPEAL. Private property owners can appeal public domain claims by the Secretary to an Administrative Law Judge within 1 year of survey approval. SEC. 5. RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN. Parcels of land in the affected area will not be treated as Federal land until the survey is completed, approved, and no further appeals are pending. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not change or affect the interest of States or sovereignty rights of federally recognized Indian tribes over lands north of the Red River's South Bank boundary line. SEC. 7. SALE OF REMAINING RED RIVER SURFACE RIGHTS. After completing the survey and ensuring no further appeals, the Secretary will offer identified Federal lands for competitive sale at fair market value. Sales are subject to existing tribal, State, and local rights. The sale of identified Federal lands under this section is subject to valid existing tribal, State, and local rights. Net proceeds from the sale will be used to offset costs associated with the Act. The Secretary must submit a report to the House of Representatives and the Senate within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must report to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment on any Federal lands not sold and reasons for non-sale. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "affected area" as lands along the Red River, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "South Bank" as a water-washed elevation along the river. The term "South Bank" refers to the water-washed elevation along the Red River that separates its bed from the adjacent upland, as specified in a decree from Oklahoma v. Texas in 1923. The "South Bank boundary line" is the boundary between Texas and Oklahoma identified through the gradient boundary survey method, as specified in a decree from Oklahoma v. Texas in 1923. The "gradient boundary survey method" is the measurement technique used for this purpose. The "gradient boundary survey method" is the measurement technique used to locate the South Bank boundary line between Texas and Oklahoma along the Red River, as established by the United States Supreme Court in a decree from 1923. The South Bank boundary along the Red River is subject to changes from erosion and accretion as specified in a 1923 decree in Oklahoma v. Texas.
